Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Random eigenvalue problems and fluctuations of large stochastic systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI will work on problems related to random matrix theory and the fluctuation theory of large stochastic systems. One of the basic problems of random matrix theory is to analyze the eigenvalues of large random matrices. The PI will focus on problems related to the asymptotic spectral properties of the beta ensembles, a family of models generalizing some of the most studied classical random matrix models (e.g. GOE, GUE, GSE, Wishart). The project builds on the recent results of the PI and collaborators in which the point process scaling limits of general beta ensembles are derived in the bulk of the spectrum. The proposed problems include the extension of methods to other random matrix ensembles, analyzing the limiting point processes and finding connections to the existing descriptions of classical cases. The approach relies on the study of random tridiagonal matrices which also provides a natural framework to investigate the asymptotic spectral properties of certain random Schrodinger operators. Non-rigorous physical scaling arguments suggest that a large class of one-dimensional random systems have unusual superdiffusive fluctuations with a scaling exponent of 2/3. Examples include interacting particle systems, growth models and directed polymers. These systems arise as models for various phenomena in the natural and social sciences. The recent decade brought a breakthrough from the mathematical side: for certain models the fluctuation exponent has been determined rigorously and in some cases even scaling limits have been proved. The PI will work towards extending the rigorous results to a wider family of models. In particular the fluctuation theory of certain lattice gases, directed polymer models and self avoiding processes will be studied.

The problems considered in the proposal deal with the analysis of systems with a large number of random components with complex interactions. We might understand the joint distribution of the entries of a large random matrix, but the distribution of the eigenvalues is usually a lot more complicated. The evolution of an interacting particle system might be simple on a local level, and we might understand the behavior of the fluctuations for a fixed time, but the scaling limit of the fluctuation field may be a highly non-trivial object. The goal of the proposal is to develop new tools and to provide a better understanding for such problems. The educational part of the proposal focuses on enhancing undergraduate and graduate probability education at the PI's host institution and actively involving graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in the PI's area of research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit


The project focused on problems related to random matrices and large stochastic systems.

One of the basic problems of random matrix theory is to analyze the eigenvalues of large random matrices, in particular to derive and describe the limiting point processes. The limit point processes of the classical random matrix models are usually described by identifying their joint intensity functions, the asymptotic probability of seeing points of the process near a given configuration of values. Recently, another characterization has been provided for these limits, as the spectra of random self-adjoint differential operators and via coupled systems of stochastic differential equations.

The PI proved a number of results related to random matrix theory. These include the derivation and study of scaling limits of certain random Schrodinger operators, the study of rare events connected to the limiting point processes of certain random matrix ensembles and how the scaling limits of a number of random matrix models can be represented using random differential operators. 

The second part of the project was related to the study of interacting stochastic systems that possess unusual scaling exponents. These are procesess with scaling behavior that is different from the diffusive scaling observed in the framework of the classical central limit theorem. The PI studied the scaling properties of various stochastic processes motivated by models from statistical physics: self-interacting diffusions, diffusions in random environment, interacting lattice gases and directed random polymers. The PI also studied matrix generalizations of certain distributional identities of Dufresne, Matsumoto and Yor which recently played an important role in the identification of certain scaling exponents. 

 

Broader Impact

Three graduate students were supported from the award: Diane Holcomb, Christopher Janjigian and Hans Chaumont. Holcomb defended her Ph.D. thesis in 2014, she is currently a Richard Pierce Postdoctoral fellow at University of Arizona. Janjigian defended his thesis in 2016, he has started a postdoctoral fellowship at the Fondation Sciences Mathematiques de Paris during the fall of 2016. The PI has started working with Hans Chaumont in 2015 on problems related to directed polymers, he is expected to graduate in 2018.

A postdoc, Gregorio Moreno Flores, was partially funded from the project in 2013, he is currently a tenure track assistant professor at the Catholic University of Chile.

The PI gave four graduate level probability courses during the award period, including two topics courses that were directly related to the topic of the grant.

The PI developed and introduced a new undergraduate course at UW-Madison during the project. The course gives a rigorous, proof-based introduction to probability theory on an advanced undergraduate level without the heavy machinery of measure theory. The course has been offered three times so far and will be offered every year. 

In a joint project with Anderson and Seppalainen the PI wrote an undergraduate textbook to be used in introductory probability courses for students with calculus background. The textbook has been used at UW–Madison since 2013, and it has been used as the main text at a number of other universities in introductory probability courses during the last couple of semesters. 

The PI has offered independent study and reading courses for a number of undergraduate students during the award period, topics included stochastic calculus and random matrix theory.

The PI has worked with two undergraduate students on summer research projects related to directed polymers and random matrices.
